abstract.text: This article grew out of the theoretical part of my Master's thesis at the Faculty of Mathematics and Information Science at Ruprecht-Karls-Universität Heidelberg under the supervision of PD Dr. Andreas Ott. Following the work of G. Carlsson and A. Zomorodian on the theory of multidimensional persistence in 2007 and 2009

, the main goal of this article is to give a complete classification and parameterization for the algebraic objects corresponding to the homology of a multifiltered simplicial complex. As in the work of G. Carlsson and A. Zomorodian, this classification and parameterization result is then used to show that it is only possible to obtain a discrete and complete invariant for these algebraic objects in the case of one-dimensional persistence, and that it is impossible to obtain the same in dimensions greater than one. *

body_text.text: Persistent homology allows us to analyze topological features of increasing filtrations of topological spaces with a complete and discrete invariant, the so-called (persistence) barcode. Many applications of topology lead to multifiltrations, e.g. if we analyze time dependent point cloud datasets as in [BBC + 21] .

In this article, we investigate the theoretical aspects of multidimensional persistence, the extension of the one dimensional concept of persistent homology. This article is mainly based on the work of G. Carlsson and A. Zomorodian in [CZ07] and [CZ09] . [CZ07] and [CZ09] are very similar where the difference is that [CZ09] digs deeper into the details. Both [CZ07] and [CZ09] contain unproven statements. So, one of our main tasks is to fill in the gaps in [CZ07] and [CZ09] . Following [CZ07] and [CZ09] , our main goal is to carry out a complete classification (Section 3) and parameterization (Section 4) of the algebraic objects that correspond to the homology of a multifiltered simplicial complex. As in [CZ07] and [CZ09] , we then use the parameterization result to show that it is only possible to obtain a discrete and complete invariant for these algebraic objects in the case of one-dimensional persistence, and that it is impossible to obtain the same in dimension greater than one. Here, a discrete invariant is an invariant which is countable in size and which takes values in the same set independently of the underlying coefficient field (see Definition 2.21 ) and a complete invariant is an invariant which is injective as a function on the objects of classification (see Definition 2.19) . At the end of Section 3, we discuss a discrete invariant for multidimensional persistence, the so-called rank invariant (introduced in [CZ07] and [CZ09] ), which is practicable for analyzing multiparamter problems and equivalent to the barcode in dimension one.

Our approach in Section 3, based on [CZ07, Sec. 4] and [CZ09, Sec. 4] , can be summarized as follows: first of all, we have to determine the algebraic objects which correspond to the homology of a finite n-filtered simplicial complex (see Section 2.2). As it turns out, any finite n-filtered simplicial complex defines a finitely generated n-graded A F n -module M where A F n = F[x 1 , . . . , x n ] (see Sections 2.3 and 3.1). Moreover, if F = F p where p ∈ N is a prime number or F = Q, any such module M can be realized as a finite n-filtered simplicial complex (see Theorem 3.5) .

For the following, denote by Grf n (A F n ) the category of finitely generated n-graded A F nmodules together with graded A F n -module homomorphisms as morphisms. In Section 3.2, we show that any M ∈ Grf n (A F n ) admits a free hull, i.e. there exists a pair (F, p) where F ∈ Grf n (A F n ) is graded free and p : F M is a graded surjective A F n -module homomorphism such that

is a graded isomorphism of n-graded F-vector spaces. Here A F n acts on F by setting the variable action identical to zero. By using an n-graded version of Nakayama's Lemma (see Lemma 3.16) , it is possible to show that (F, p) is a free hull of M if and only if p maps a homogeneous A F n -basis of F to a minimal system of homogeneous generators of M (see Proposition 3.20) .
Every graded free F ∈ Grf n (A F n ) admits a graded isomorphism

The main theorem on free hulls (see Theorem 3.12) states that free hulls are unique up to isomorphism and that every M ∈ Grf n (A F n ) admits a free hull p : F F n (ξ) − M for a finite n-dimensional multiset ξ. If (F F n (ξ), p) is a free hull of M , then ξ is also called the type of M . If G ⊆ M is a minimal set of homogeneous generators of M , the multiset ξ tells us in which degrees the generators in G are located. Free hulls can be viewed as the basic building block of a minimal graded free resolution of M (see Remark 3.25 ).
Let us denote by Grf n (A F n )/∼ = the set of all isomorphism classes [M ] of objects M ∈ Grf n (A F n ). Indeed, Grf n (A F n )/∼ = is a set (see Proposition 3.23) . Denote by

the subset of all [M ] such that M admits a free hull p 0 : F F n (ξ 0 ) M and ker(p 0 ) admits a free hull p 1 : F F n (ξ 1 ) ker(p 0 ). Let L ⊆ F F n (ξ 0 ) be a graded A F n -submodule. We say that L satisfies the tensor-condition (see Section 3.3.2) if the image of the induced morphism
is zero. Denote by S F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 ) the set of all graded A F n -submodules L ⊆ F F n (ξ 0 ) of type ξ 1 which satisfy the tensor-condition.
As in [CZ09, Sec. 4.5] , we obtain a well-defined set theoretic surjection S F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 ) − I F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 ), L − [F F n (ξ 0 )/L].

Without the tensor-condition this map would not be well-defined. In [CZ07] and [CZ09] , the tensor-condition is missing. This surjection induces a set theoretic bijection S F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 )/Aut(F F n (ξ 0 ))

which provides a complete classification of I F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 ) (see Theorem 3.29 and [CZ09, Thm. 9] ). Now the question is if there exists a discrete parameterization of S F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 )/Aut(F F n (ξ 0 )).

In Section 3.6, we approach this question by considering a possible candidate for a discrete and complete invariant for Grf n (A F n )/∼ = , the so-called rank invariant (introduced in [CZ07, Sec. 6] and [CZ09, Sec. 6] ). In dimension n = 1, the rank invariant is equivalent to the barcode (see Theorem 3.36 ) and defines hence a complete and discrete invariant (see [CZ07, Thm. 5] and [CZ09, Thm. 12] ). So, the rank invariant can be viewed as a discrete generalization of the barcode to dimension n ≥ 2. But as we will see in Section 4, the rank invariant is not complete in dimension n ≥ 2.

In Section 4, our first goal is to show that for n ≥ 2, there exists no discrete and complete invariant for Grf n (A F n )/∼ = . For this, we parameterize S F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 ) as a subset of a product of Grassmannians together with a group action of Aut(F F n (ξ 0 )). This approach follows [CZ07, Sec. 5] and [CZ09, Sec. 5] By using the parameterization result (see Theorems 4.2 and 4.22), we see that S F 2 (ξ 0 , ξ 1 ) is in bijection to a fourfold product of the Grassmannian G F (1, 2) . Note that G F (1, 2) equals the projective line P 1 (F). The automorphism group Aut(F F 2 (ξ 0 )) is isomorphic to GL 2 (F) (see Proposition 4.12) . Thus, we obtain set theoretic bijections
and I F 2 (ξ 0 , ξ 1 ) ∼ = P 1 (F) 4 /GL 2 (F) is uncountable if F is uncountable. For n > 2, we just have to append zeros to the entries of ξ 0 and ξ 1 .

Based on and inspired by [CZ07, Sec. 5] and [CZ09, Sec. 5] , Section 4.5 is devoted to the investigation of goal number two in Section 4: showing that S F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 ), which we have paramterized as a subset of a product of Grassmannians, corresponds to the set of F-points of an algebraic variety together with an algebraic group action of Aut(F F n (ξ 0 )). In other words, we want to give an explicit parameterization of the moduli space of our classification problem.

1. X is called n-filtered if X = u∈N n X u for an n-filtration of simplicial complexes (X u ) u∈N n which stabilizes. X is called multifiltered if X is n-filtered for some n ∈ N. We often write X = (X u ) u∈N n to indicate that X is an n-filtered simplicial complex with X = u∈N n X u .
2. X is called a finite n-filtered simplicial complex if X is an n-filtered simplicial complex and if X is finite (i.e. the set of vertices of X is finite).

Remark 2.11. If S is a commutative ring and N a finitely generated S-module, then every minimal generating set of N has finite length: let G be a finite generating set of N and G a minimal generating set. Then any g ∈ G is a linear combination of finitely many elements g ∈ G . Since G is finite and G is minimal, G has to be finite. In particular, if N is free, then every basis of N has finite length (every basis is a minimal generating set).

As we have already mentioned in the introduction, this section is devoted to the classification of finitely generated n-graded A F n -modules. In Section 3.1, we answer the question of how the study of the homology of a finite n-filtered simplicial complex translates naturally into the study of finitely generated n-graded A F n -modules. In Section 3.2, we present the theory behind free hulls. Free hulls are the basic building block for the complete classification of finitely generated n-graded A F n -modules. This complete classification is then carried out in Section 3.3. To approach the question of whether this classification can provide a complete and discrete class of invariants, we first review the one-dimensional case in Section 3.5, where the barcode provides a complete and discrete class of invariants. Then we turn our attention to the rank invariant for multidimensional persistence, which is discrete and equivalent to the barcode in dimension n = 1. But as we will see in Section 4, there is no complete and discrete class of invariants in dimension n ≥ 2.

The first goal of this section is to show that for n ≥ 2, there exists no class

of invariants which is complete and discrete. As {J F n } F∈K is complete, it suffices to show that {J F n } F∈K is not discrete for n ≥ 2 by Proposition 2.20. Let ξ 0 and ξ 1 be two finite n-dimensional multisets. In Sections 4.1-4.3, we parameterize S F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 ) as a subset of a product of Grassmannians together with a group action of Aut(F F n (ξ 0 )). This approach follows [CZ07, Sec. 4.3] and [CZ09, Sec. 5] . However, the authors ommited proofs and details. We fill in the gaps and give detailed proofs. Using this parameterization, we show the non-existence of a discrete and complete class of invariants in Section 4.4.

In Section 4.5, we investigate the second goal of this section: that this subset corresponds to the set of F-points of an algebraic variety together with an algebraic group action of Aut(F F n (ξ 0 )). In other words, we want to give an explicit parameterization of the moduli space of our classification problem. Here we follow [CZ07, Sec. 5] and [CZ09, Sec. 5] . In Section 4.5.1, we construct a subprevariety Y F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 ) of a product of Grassmann varieties (over F) such that Y F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 )(F) ∼ = S F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 ).

In Section 4.5.2, we give some ideas that provide evidence for how this can be done. For Grassmann varieties (and therefore also for products of Grassmann varieties) this problem is also technical but solved (see for instance [GW10, (8.4) ]). Since Y F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 ) is constructed as a subprevariety of a product of Grassmann varieties, we use the approach for Grassmann varieties. In [CZ09, Sec. 5] , the authors give a proof for the subprevariety-part which does not contain an interpretation of the tensor-condition in terms of polynomial equations. In [CZ07, Thm. 4] , the subprevariety-part is stated where in comparison to [CZ09, Sec. 5] a proof and conditions are missing. In [CZ07, Thm. 4] and [CZ09, Sec. 5] , the authors claim (without a proof) that the action is algebraic.

In this section, we give some ideas that provide evidence why the action of GL F (ξ 0 ) on Y F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 ) is algebraic. In this section, we use the same notations as in the proofs of Theorems 4.32 and 4.33.First of all note that for every m ∈ N, there exists an algebraic F-group GL F m such that for any T ∈ NAlg F GL F m (T ) = GL m (T ).GL F m is given as the affine Noetherian F-schemeGL F m is called the general linear group scheme (see [GW10, 4.4.3] ). Recall thatThen there exists a closed subscheme GL F (ξ 0 ) ⊆ GL F m 0 such that for any T ∈ NAlg F ,which we obtain by setting the variables in F[(x ij )][det(x ij ) −1 ], which correspond to M (v i , v j ), equal to zero. It remains to show that GL F (ξ 0 ) ⊆ GL F m 0 is an algebraic subgroup. Now we turn our attention to the determination of Y F n (ξ 0 , ξ 1 )(T ) for T ∈ NAlg F . In the following, we often refer to [EH00, Ex. VI-18]. Note that our notations are different and that we are in the relative setting over F.
